# Conditional Text Extension Demo

This document demonstrates the conditional text extension for Quarto. You can select different versions of content using the version selector above.

## Block-level Conditional Content

Here's how to read data from a CSV file in different languages:

::: {.conditional-text version="python"}
### Python Example

Use pandas to read CSV data:

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv('data.csv')
print(data.head())
```
:::

::: {.conditional-text version="r"}
### R Example

Use readr to read CSV data:

```r
library(readr)
data <- read_csv('data.csv')
head(data)
```
:::

::: {.conditional-text version="julia"}
### Julia Example

Use CSV.jl to read CSV data:

```julia
using CSV, DataFrames
data = CSV.read("data.csv", DataFrame)
first(data, 5)
```
:::

## Inline Conditional Content

You can also use conditional text inline. For example, you might want to use
[pandas]{.conditional-text version="python"}
[readr]{.conditional-text version="r"}
[CSV.jl]{.conditional-text version="julia"}
to read your data files.

## Different Styling

You can apply different styling to your conditional blocks:

:::

::: {.conditional-text version="r" .alert .alert-info}

:::

::: {.conditional-text version="julia" .alert .alert-warning}

:::

## Operating System Specific Instructions

::: {.conditional-text version="windows"}
### Windows Setup

To install the package on Windows:

```bash
pip install package
```
:::

::: {.conditional-text version="mac"}
### Mac Setup

To install the package on Mac:

```bash
pip3 install package
```
:::

::: {.conditional-text version="linux"}
### Linux Setup

To install the package on Linux:

```bash
sudo pip install package
```
:::
